content.html:
A year of new avenues

All along, from the frothy 1990s to the perÂ­coÂ­latÂ­ing 2000s to the frozen 2010s to today, the web has been the sure thing. All along, itâ€™s been growÂ­ing and maturing, sproutÂ­ing new capabilities. From my vanÂ­tage point, that growth has seemed to accelÂ­erÂ­ate in the past five years; CSS, in parÂ­ticÂ­uÂ­lar, has become incredÂ­iÂ­bly flexÂ­iÂ­ble and expressive. Maybe even a bit overstuffedâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut Iâ€™ll takeÂ it.

For peoÂ­ple who care about creÂ­atÂ­ing worlds together, rather than getÂ­ting rich, the web is the past and the web is the future. What luck, that this decentralized, perÂ­misÂ­sionÂ­less sysÂ­tem claimed a posiÂ­tion at the heart of the interÂ­net, and stuck there. Itâ€™s limited, of course; frustrating; someÂ­times maddening. But thatâ€™s every creÂ­ative medium. Thatâ€™sÂ life.

content.html:
I decided to listen to what the universe was trying to tell me.

Turns out the universe is mostly just sick and tired of being anthropomorphised.

content.html:
My upcoming appearance at An Event Apart next week to talk about declarative design isnâ€™t the only upcoming trip to San Francisco in my calendar.

Two months from today Iâ€™ll be back in San Francisco for Leading Design. Itâ€™s on February 7th and 8th.

This event is long overdue. Weâ€™ve never had Leading Design in San Francisco before, but we were all set to go ahead with the inaugural SF gathering â€¦in March 2020. We all know what happened next.

So this event will be three years in the making.

Rebacca is doing amazing work, as usual, putting together a fantastic line-up of speakers:

Theyâ€™ll be sharing their insights, their stories and their ideas â€” as well as some of their pain from past challenges. Itâ€™s all designed to help you navigate your own leadership journey.

Iâ€™ll be there to MC the event, which is a great honour for me. And I reckon Iâ€™ll be up to the challenge, having just done the double whammy of hosting Leading Design London and Clarity back-to-back.

I would love to see you in San Francisco! If youâ€™ve attended a Leading Design event before, then you know how transformational it can be. If you havenâ€™t, then now is your chance.

Early bird tickets are still available until mid December, so if youâ€™re thinking about coming, I suggest making that decision now.

If you know anyone in the bay area whoâ€™s in a design leadership position, be sure to tell them about Leading Design San Franciscoâ€”they donâ€™t want to miss this!

content.html:
Jamie Freeman passed away yesterday.

I first met Jamie as a fellow web-nerd way back in the early 2000s when I was freelancing here in Brighton. I did a lot of work with him and his design studio, Message. Andy was working there too. Itâ€™s kind of where the seeds of Clearleft were planted.

I remember one day telling them about a development with Salter Cane. Our drummer, Catherine, was moving to Australia so we were going to have to start searching for someone new.

â€œI play drumsâ€, said Jamie.

I remember thinking, â€œNo, you donâ€™t; you play guitar.â€ But I thought â€œWhat the heckâ€, and invited him along to a band practice.

Well, it turns that not only could he play drums, he was really good! Jamie was in the band.

Itâ€™s funny, I kept referring to Jamie as â€œour new drummerâ€, but he actually ended up being the drummer that was with Salter Cane the longest.

Band practices. Concerts. Studio recordings. We were a team for years. You can hear Jamieâ€™s excellent drumming on our album Sorrow. You can also his drumming (and brilliant backing vocals) on an album of covers we recorded. He was such a solid drummerâ€”he made the whole band sound tighter.

But as brilliant as Jamie was behind a drumkit, his heart was at the front of the stage. He left Salter Cane to front The Jamie Freeman Agreement full-time. I loved going to see that band and watching them get better and better. Jonathan has written lovingly about his time with the band.

After that, Jamie continued to follow his dreams as a solo performer, travelling to Nashville, and collaborating with loads of other talented people. Everyone loved Jamie.

This year started with the shocking news that he had inoperable cancerâ€”a brain tumor. Everyone sent him all their love (we recorded a little video from the Salter Cane practice roomâ€”as his condition worsened, video worked better than writing). But somehow I didnâ€™t quite believe that this day would come when Jamie was no longer with us. I mean, the thought was ridiculous: Jamie, the vegetarian tea-totaller â€¦with cancer? Nah.

I think Iâ€™m still in denial.

The last time I had the joy of playing music with Jamie was also the last time that Salter Cane played a gig. Jamie came back for a one-off gig at the start of 2020 (before the world shut down). It was joyous. It felt so good to rock out with him.

Jamie was always so full of enthusiasm for other people, whether that was his fellow musicians or his family members. He had great stories from his time on tour with his brother Timâ€™s band, Frazier Chorus. And he was so, so proud of everything his brother Martin has done. It was so horrible when their sister died. I canâ€™t imagine what they must be going through now, losing another sibling.

Like I said, I still canâ€™t quite believe that Jamie has gone. I know that Iâ€™m really going to miss him.

Iâ€™m sending all my love and my deepest sympathies to Jamieâ€™s family.

Fuck cancer.

Fuck cancer.

content.html:
Iâ€™ve always liked the idea that your website can be your API. Like, youâ€™ve already got URLs to identify resources, so why not make that URL structure predictable and those resources parsable?

Thatâ€™s why the (read-only) API for The Session doesnâ€™t live at a separate subdomain. It uses the same URL structure as the regular site, but you can request the resources in an alternative format: JSON, XML, RSS.

This works out pretty well, mostly because I put a lot of thought into the URL structure of the site. Iâ€™m something of a URL fetishist, but I think that taking a URL-first approach to information architecture can be a good exercise.

Most of the resources on The Session involve nouns like tunes, events, discussions, and so on. Thereâ€™s a consistent and predictable structure to the URLs for those sections:

  • /things
  • /things/new
  • /things/search

And then an idividual item can be found at:

  • things/ID

Thatâ€™s all nice and predictable and the naming of the URLs matches what youâ€™d expect to find:

  • tunes
  • tunes/new
  • tunes/search?q=Ireland
  • tunes/320

Tunes, events, discussions, sessions. Those are all fine. But thereâ€™s one section of the site that has this root URL:

/recordings

When I was coming up with the URL structure twenty years ago, it was clear what youâ€™d find there: track listings for albums of music. No one wouldâ€™ve expected to find actual recordings of music available to listen to on-demand. The bandwidth constraints and technical limitations of the time made that clear.

Two decades on, the situation has changed. Now someone new to the site might well expect to hit a link called â€œrecordingsâ€ and expect to hear actual recordings of music.

So I should probably change the label on the link. I donâ€™t think â€œalbumsâ€ is quite rightâ€”what even is an album any more? The word â€œdiscographyâ€ is probably the most appropriate label.

Hereâ€™s my dilemma: if I update the label, should I also update the URL structure?

Right now, the section of the site with /tunes URLs is labelled â€œtunesâ€. The section of the site with /events URLs is labelled â€œeventsâ€. Currently the section of the site with /recordings URLs is labelled â€œrecordingsâ€, but may soon be labelled â€œdiscographyâ€.

If you click on â€œtunesâ€, you end up at /tunes. But if you click on â€œdiscographyâ€, you end up at /recordings.

Is that okay? Am I the only one that would be bothered by that?

I could update the URLs to match the labelling (with redirects for the old URLs, of course), but Iâ€™m not so keen on this URL structure:

  • /discography
  • /discography/new
  • /discography/search
  • /discography/ID

It doesnâ€™t seem as tidy as:

  • /recordings
  • /recordings/new
  • /recordings/search
  • /recordings/ID

But if I donâ€™t update the URLs to match the label, then Iâ€™m just going to have to live with the mismatch.

Iâ€™m just thinking out loud here. I think I should definitely update the label. I just wonâ€™t make any decision on changing URLs for a while yet.

Transient Frameworks Â· Matthias Ott â€“ User Experience Designer

Frameworks come and go. They are transient. Web standards, on the other hand, are the reason the Web is good now and it will become even better in the future.

content.html:
Simon Collison | Farewell, Twitter

Iâ€™ve been feeling exactly what Colly articulates here:

Iâ€™m aware that smart friends still tweet passing thoughts without a care, and I canâ€™t understand why. Some seem happy to repost damning articles about the situation and then carry on tweeting without a care.

content.html:
A few weeks back, a friend likened something I said to what Elon Musk would say.

They retracted, but with each of Muskâ€™s unhinged proclamations, the insult grows like a virus.

Iâ€™m honestly not sure our friendship can get past it.
